data.text: Contents
Introduction
Historically, patients with traumatic brain injuries have been admitted to hospital under the care of the General Surgical teams in the UK.
This may not be the best place for admission as the majority have no need for any surgical intervention and certainly this would not be undertaken by the general surgical team.
Treating most of these patients increasingly entails supporting the recovery from the injury and addressing the underlying causes of the fall is the desired patient centred outcome.

This is ideally achieved by the multidisciplinary approach utilised by the Frailty Team and the Internal Medical Team for the cohort of patients over the age of 75 years with a CFS of 4 or more and a TBI classified as minor (GCS 14-15.)
Scope
This policy applies to patients over the age of 75 with a CFS of 4 or more and a traumatic head injury requiring conservative management.
There will be individual case by case patient discussions meaning that younger frail patients with a CFS of 4 or more may well be cared for within this guideline.
Patients are grouped into GCS>13 or GCS≤13, or a 2-point drop on their baseline conscious level if not normally GCS 15.
Definitions
Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Trauma Lead- to ensure policy is maintained and implemented
Divisional Director for Medicine/Frailty with the Clinical Director for General Surgery address any concerns arising from the introduction of this policy
Background

Patients with head injuries over the age of 75 with frailty syndrome (defined here as a CFS ofor more for the purposes of this pathway,) are most frequently injured by falling from standing in their own homes. They rarely require or are accepted for acute neurosurgical intervention.
There is rarely any indication for any neurosurgical intervention with even those sustaining severe injuries unlikely to benefit from a surgical procedure.

Patients with clearly abnormal CT imaging are managed according to GCS with very few being accepted for immediate transfer. The neurosurgical advice for acute subdural haematoma for example is usually for observation only with re-imaging and further discussion if the GCS drops.

For patients with GCS 13 or less the advice is to re-image in 2 weeks and they may consider transfer of patients once the subdural has become chronic, and established, and the patient is still symptomatic or functionally impaired. This secondary transfer for neurosurgical intervention is a rare event. Transfer for intervention usually happens after the primary discussion with the neurosurgical service when the patient is in ED and they are never admitted to the care of an inpatient team locally.

This patient population if ≥75 years old with the frailty syndrome (CFS 4 or more,) is therefore much better served by admission either to the frailty unit if capacity exists or, under the medical teams where their frailty syndromes and complex co-morbid conditions can be addressed.

Neurological observations and the holistic package of care needed by this patient group are better delivered on the medical wards. Carrying out neuro-observations is a generic skill required by all nursing staff on medical wards.
Admission pathway
All patients with a head injury should be assessed in the ED in line with the NICE Guidelines and ATLS principles.
CT imaging of the head and cervical spine should have been carried in line with NICE CG176 (last updated Sept 2019.)
Imaging must have been reported and the result documented in the notes.

Any abnormal reports must have been referred and discussed with the neurosurgical service at Addenbrooke's via the Orion cloud portal and by telephone when necessary. We are part of the East of England Trauma Network therefore Addenbrooke's Hospital / Cambridge University Hospital is our referral centre for Traumatic Brain Injury. Please do not refer patients with traumatic head injuries to Queen's Hospital in Romford.
Neurosurgical advice must be documented in the notes including printouts of any responses via the Orion Cloud referral portal.

All anticoagulants must be withheld and reversed as per neurosurgical service and local haematology consultant advice. Advice for reversing anti-coagulation should also be sought from the cardiology service for patients with metallic heart valves.
Repeat clotting studies must be sent and results documented in the notes post reversal.

Tranexamic acid 1g IV over 10 minutes followed 1g IV over 8 hrs by infusion should considered in all patients with mild to moderate TBI and abnormal CT imaging demonstrating Intracerebral haemorrhage. (All cause mortality was reduced from 14.0% to 12.5% in a recent large multi-centre double blind RCT - CRASH 3. There is no benefit to patients with severe head injuries defined as GCS 8 or less.)
Discussion with the EPIC bleep holder must have taken place and the name of this senior clinician documented clearly in the notes.
Relevant DNACPR and TEP completed.
The EPIC doctors decision about the admitting specialty will be accepted by the specialist teams.

Patients in whom the neurosurgeons advise a repeat CT at 48 hrs electively must be admitted under the surgical team, unless a consultant-to-consultant discussion between surgery and frailty (medicine out of hours) has taken place, and it is agreed that it is not in the patient's best interest and further surgical intervention is not appropriate.

Patients in whom the neuro-surgical advice is to manage conservatively according to NICE guidelines and only repeat CT if there is a drop in GCS must be admitted under frailty if they fulfil criteria unless a consultant-to-consultant discussion between surgery and frailty (medicine out of hours) has taken place.
Neurosurgical advice
Clear written advice from the tertiary centre is needed to enact this pathway
A decision must be made as to whether the scans, combined with the clinical representation, in the referral would make any further imaging or observation in the patient's best interest.
If they are not planning to take the patient immediately then a decision regarding what to do in the event of a neurological deterioration must be made. This MUST be made clear in the referral.
Patients in whom the neurosurgeons advise a repeat CT scan at 48hrs who would be considered for neurosurgical intervention MUST be admitted under the surgical team regardless of their age or CFS.
Inclusion criteria
Onto the >75 TBI
Must have an ISOLATED TBI.
MUST have a GCS of ≥14 or be 0-1 point below the patient's baseline function.
No unstable cervical vertebral or other spinal column fractures / unstable ligament injuries.
Anticoagulation fully reversed or withheld as appropriate, rationale documented and necessary discussions with haematology documented.
Normal CT or CT findings not requiring neurosurgical intervention with neurosurgical plan from Orion cloud documented in the notes.
Exclusion criteria
For the >75 pathway for TBI
Aged  and/or CFS  over  with a good functional status and CFS<4 should be admitted under the surgical team on call.)
Patients in whom a repeat CT at 48 hrs is mandated in the neurosurgical plan with intention to consider surgery based on this repeat scan.
Suspected or confirmed unstable spinal fractures / ligament injuries requiring immobilisation.
Associated surgical and/ or orthopaedic injuries requiring intervention / treatment.
Lower limb fractures requiring POP cast and non-weight baring status.
Upper limb fractures in patients that result in reduced mobility and inpatient stay of >72 hrs is likely. These patients should be admitted under the orthopaedic team.
Patients >75 who are accepted for neurosurgical intervention and not transferred immediately from the ED must be admitted under the general surgical team if transfer is planned at any time.

Patients with cervical spine fractures and significant head injury with abnormal CT finding must be admitted under the orthopaedic team with input from the general surgical team for management of the head injury.
Training requirements
Education of the Frailty and Medical teams relating to the implementation of the policy and any concerns
Education of the ED teams in the utilisation of the policy

The East of England Trauma Network, NICE Guidelines on Trauma Service Delivery (NG40) and NHSi Operational Delivery Network policies state that there must be one person within each Trauma Unit from a nursing background with clinical oversight of all patients within the hospital with serious injury and major trauma (ISS 9-15 and >15 respectively.)

data.url: 20006 Head injury pathway for patients over 75 years old 2.0.031.png

data.text: There has not been a single Trauma Co-ordinator within MEHT with responsibility for clinical oversight of all trauma patients and there is no-one person currently with the necessary training, knowledge and experience to facilitate this. However, we do have a wealth of knowledge and experience throughout the trust in the form of CNSs and experienced senior nursing staff on SEW who already deal directly with trauma patients. The Pain Team, Falls, Orthopaedic CNSs and SEW Matron / Senior Sisters are ideally placed to identify trauma patients to the TARN co-ordinator (KQ.) The TARN co-ordinator will run a real time database of all patients with an ISS>8 to capture them for entry into the TARN database. Submitting complete and accurate TARN data is vital to accurately monitor our care for trauma patients and to identify necessary improvements in care.

Clinical support for her will be supplied daily by the orthopaedic trauma co-ordinators and the Trust Trauma Lead if necessary. Paul Heard our Band 7 Orthopaedic Co-ordinator will act as the point of contact for clinical queries from external healthcare organisations in working hours.

There has been recognition within the trust that frail elderly patients who require admission for isolated head injuries are not best served by being managed by the general surgical team. The cause of the head injury is most often a fall from standing at  home  with  underlying  multiple  co-morbidities  /  frailty  as  the  cause.  Any  patient  suitable  for  acute  neurosurgical intervention is transferred directly from the ED without admission to an inpatient bed. The vast majority of the remainder are declined any acute intervention even in the event of deterioration as the outcomes are very poor in this patient population. Most have small traumatic SAH, small sub-dural haematomas or intra-parenchymal bleeds. Neuro-observations can just as well be done on a medical ward / frailty ward where the patients multiple additional medical needs can be better addressed. Admission under general surgery for 24-48hrs simply delays addressing these needs, the causes of the falls, contributes to the deconditioning of the patient and increases hospital length of stay. Carrie Tyler our Falls CNS is ideally placed to have oversight of patients with head injuries within the trust as she has been heavily involvePad gine  the  omf ana gement of frail elderly patients with significant Traumatic Brain Injuries due to falls.
